definition: to put/to place/to release/to free/to let go/to let out/to set off (fireworks)
gall bladder/courage/guts/gall/inner container (e.g. bladder of a football, inner container of a thermos)

sentences.english: Wherefore, though I might be much bold in Christ to enjoin thee that which is convenient
sentences.chinese: 我虽然靠着基督能放胆吩咐你合宜的事。

sentences.english: If new strategies are required, companies must be bold enough to adopt them and change their organizations.
sentences.chinese: 需要新战略，就必须放胆采纳，把公司结构换掉。

sentences.english: I am now more daring and confident in using my own mindset and my knowledge to handle the job, " he said."
sentences.chinese: 我现在可以放胆尝试用自己的方法及知识工作。

sentences.english: I must identify it, and then run.
sentences.chinese: 我必须要辨明它，且放胆奔跑。

sentences.english: If new strategies are required, companies must be bold enough to adopt them and change their organisations accordingly.
sentences.chinese: 需要新战略，就必须放胆采纳，把公司结构换掉。

definition: to reveal the truth/to spill the beans
to let oneself go/to do as much as one pleases
without concealing anything/to pass away/to die
displaying fully/developing to the greatest extent
memorial tablet in a temple commemorating a deceased father
solely engrossed in one thing/just (one thing, no need to worry about the rest)/simply/by all means/please feel free/do not hesitate (to ask for sth)
without any fear of consequences/totally devoid of scruples
